title: (2013) Throwing Muses - Purgatory-Paradise [320 kbps] {100.XY}
description:
Throwing Muses - Purgatory/Paradise


image Wikipedia:
Throwing Muses is an alternative rock band formed in 1981 in Newport, Rhode Island, that toured and recorded extensively until 1997, when its members began concentrating more on other projects. The group was originally fronted by two lead singers, Kristin Hersh and Tanya Donelly, who both wrote the group's songs. Throwing Muses are known for performing music with shifting tempos, creative chord progressions, unorthodox song structures, and surreal lyrics. The group was set apart from other contemporary acts by Hersh's stark, candid writing style; Donelly's pop stylings and vocal harmonies; and David Narcizo's unusual drumming techniques eschewing use of cymbals. Hersh's hallucinatory, febrile songs occasionally touched on the subject of mental illness, more often drawing portraits of characters from daily life or addressing relationships.



image Review:
ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a moment during the commentary packaged with Throwing Muses new album Purgatory/Paradise, after drummer Dave Narcizo offers up a particularly ribald interpretation of Ã¢â‚¬Å“SlippershellÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, where Kristin Hersh stops and laughs away the credit: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sure. God wrote it.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ From almost anyone else, that would come off ridiculous, a megalomaniacÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s humblebrag, but from Hersh itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s part of the origin story, the one thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been repeated in everything written about Throwing Muses from the 80s onward. Hersh has always held that sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not a songwriter so much as a woman accosted by songs; her role, she says, is more like a transcriptionist, or a vessel. Anything an outside audience might hear in them, the story goes, is coincidental. But Throwing MusesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ music never sounded like it sprung from any outside source so much as one thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s deeply personalÃ‚Â­Ã‚Â­. The chords lurch like feelings would; and the lyrics make internal sense. A track like Ã¢â‚¬Å“FishÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ becomes far less surreal when you know that itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s referring to an actual fish nailed to an actual cross on HershÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s actual apartment wall, but even then itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s like listening in on a few minutes of monologue, raw and untranslated, where the bits of dialogue, snippets of images, and the rest of the stuff of someone elseÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s inner life may well be a foreign language. There are plenty of Throwing Muses tracks that are obliqueÃ¢â‚¬â€and a lot more than the band gets credit for that are needle-directÃ¢â‚¬â€but few that explain themselves.

If this sounds at odds with finding a large audience, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s because it is. Throwing MusesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ time on Warner in the 90s was neither pleasant nor lucrative. Hersh gave the label the rights to Hips and Makers to get out of her contract before releasing 1996Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Limbo, a title that now seems either prescient or biting. The Muses went on hiatusÃ¢â‚¬â€or Ã¢â‚¬Å“disbanded,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ which is both farther from the truth and closer to the practical reality. Hersh released solo albums on a fairly steady schedule, but Throwing Muses released only one more record: the triumphant Throwing Muses. That was in 2003. Hersh formed another project, 50 Foot Wave, around this time, but their last two EPs were released for free and quietlyÃ¢â‚¬â€as quietly, that is, as is possible for a band whose founding principle was Ã¢â‚¬Å“Throwing Muses, if they were faster, meaner and also swore a lot.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ HershÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s last solo album, Crooked, was self-released in 2009 nearly as quietly, supported mostly by house shows and smallish acoustic concerts. And though demos of Purgatory/Paradise existed online as early as 2007 (a few were meant for Crooked), the audience they found was largely the same fans who crowdfunded the record. (Hersh was among the first to adopt the pay-what-you-want and subscription models Kickstarter and its ilk would later make inescapable.) While Throwing Muses did tour behind 2011Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Anthology compilation, it would have taken close attention to think new material was forthcoming.

Purgatory/Paradise, as it turns out, is the MusesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ first album in 10 years, and Ã¢â‚¬Å“the work [the band] can die after releasing,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ as Hersh jokes early in the commentary. (Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re really looking forward to death. We work so hard to be allowed to die!Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½) But while 2003Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Throwing Muses was a comeback album in the familiar sense, roaring and tearing at all expectations from the first count-off, Purgatory/Paradise is more reserved. Of the MusesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ albums, it most resembles Red Heaven or Limbo, the forcefully aloof deep cuts of the MusesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ discographyÃ¢â‚¬â€but a shattered version, Ã¢â‚¬Å“like someone reached over our heads with a Looney Tunes mallet and slammed it into our record before we could stop him,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Hersh wrote. (Like Crooked, Purgatory/Paradise was devised both as a record and as a book, with essays by Hersh and art by Narcizo. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s both a gorgeous standalone objectÃ¢â‚¬â€particularly the writing, considering 2010Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s Rat Girl proved Hersh one of the best music writers aroundÃ¢â‚¬â€and a sort of decoder for the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s tracks.) Half of the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s 32 tracks barely make it over two minutes. Some of them are reprises; sometimes the reprises come first. Some tracks are lopped-off bridges or choruses, or thoughts beginning with Ã¢â‚¬Å“and.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s even more disorienting for cuts like Ã¢â‚¬Å“StaticÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ whose uncut versions have been around long enough to memorize. This doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t necessarily seem odd for a band whose songs tend to skitter into loping girl-group choruses halfway or careen through dozens of chords that wouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t normally touch or scare-quote the entirety of some kidÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s anarchy pamphlet as an intro, but Purgatory/Paradise really is unlike anything IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve heard this year; itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a little like someone read an old Muses review that talked about their songs switching gears, recorded what they thought that sounded like, then lost half the data to a defragmenting snafu.

Not that Purgatory/Paradise is difficult or inaccessible. The beginning fakes you out with the almost stately folk of Ã¢â‚¬Å“Smoky HandsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just scene-setting before a song accosts you: a crash, then Ã¢â‚¬Å“Morning BirdsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, an onslaught of shredding then pathos thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s as wrenching as anything on the first Muses record. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sunray VenusÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, the single, comes shortly after, and itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s as joyous as Ã¢â‚¬Å“Morning BirdsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is visceral. Like Wild FlagÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬Å“RomanceÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s an exuberant ode to band chemistry that plays out like the Muses rediscovering all their hits (Ã¢â‚¬Å“leaving, that is limboÃ¢â‚¬â€hey, I remember you!Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½) and comes with a splashy video full of wordplay and intertextual Easter eggs. Later on is Ã¢â‚¬Å“SleepwalkingÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, a college-rock throwback where everything from the guitar lines to the glaze of the vocal processing seems imported from 1992. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d be shameless if it werenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t so huge (and self-aware; the band calls it their Ã¢â‚¬Å“RC Cola songÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½), and itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s easy to imagine it on Doolittle or Last SplashÃ¢â‚¬â€or for that matter Throwing Muses again; you can even trace out where Tanya DonellyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s harmonies would go.

But thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the second version of Ã¢â‚¬Å“SleepwalkingÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ you hear: the first version is what would ordinarily be end of the song, a one-minute acoustic hangover. Songs come and go like this, or more specifically moments: bassist Bernard GeorgesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ sly lead on Ã¢â‚¬Å“Cherry CandyÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, the spy riff and ballroom pirouette of a drum fill that introduces Ã¢â‚¬Å“FilmÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ or the piano waltz it becomes halfway, the panflutes of Ã¢â‚¬Å“Folding FireÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ (if any instrumentÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s unexpected on a Throwing Muses album, that would be it), certain melodies that recur or slip into the wrong tracks. The album, to its credit, rarely feels indulgentÃ¢â‚¬â€only the two aimless Ã¢â‚¬Å“CurtainsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ stand out as possible editsÃ¢â‚¬â€and the more you listen, the more a method emerges from the muddle.

Purgatory/Paradise, more than any of HershÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s records to date, is an album about loss, which might account for its fracturing. The closest thing to a traditionally built song is the bitterly determined Ã¢â‚¬Å“MilanÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, about a neighborhood in New Orleans where Hersh's house was destroyed after Hurricane Katrina. Everything else is tentative: memories listed in order of disapperance. Sometimes the loss is literal, as in Ã¢â‚¬Å“StaticÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, written for a close friend who died; the arrangement tiptoes at first, then plunges straight into denial. Sometimes itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s almost funny: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Terra NovaÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, about the MusesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ first breakup, is aimless and resigned, melodies delivered like shrugs, until it breaks out the Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bittersweet SymphonyÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ strings. Sometimes itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not funny at all, as on Ã¢â‚¬Å“Quick,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ a song built uneasily atop a cello dirge, or Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bluff,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ which is a curious lilting minute at first until its essay turns hazy into heartbreaking: Ã¢â‚¬Å“If you watch your friends carefully, sometimes you'll notice their features beginning to change: curling up into themselves, looking within rather than without, their senses dulled.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ (The more I listen, the more it seems like a direct companion to Ã¢â‚¬Å“FloodingÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, the saddest song Hersh has ever recorded.)

Purgatory/Paradise isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t an easy listenÃ¢â‚¬â€expected enough from a band thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s repeatedly referred to the recording process as being Ã¢â‚¬Å“on a [desert] island". If Throwing Muses didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t explain themselves before, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re certainly not doing so now, and for a comeback album, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s so willfully at odds with any music consumption trend in 2013. Even as you imagine what these songs used to sound like, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s hard to imagine actually listening to them that way, let alone shuffled in with anything else; its pieces are simply too small and elusive to listen to individually. TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d sound out of place on playlists, maybe bewildered in setlists. But as Hersh wrote to accompany Ã¢â‚¬Å“Swollen,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ an album offcut (though the essay did become the introduction to the book), Ã¢â‚¬Å“It is not un-beautiful to be in pieces, as long as those pieces are fully realized.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ It may be impossible for Throwing Muses to write anything that isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t. 
Review By Katherine St. Asaph [8.0/10]
